standard_metadata.standard_description: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Write decimals and fractions greater than 1 shown on number lines

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a fraction and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 3 to 5, with 10 equal sections between each whole number. A point labeled question mark is 2 sections to the right of 4.

hints.content: There are $10$ equal distances between each two whole numbers on the number line.
Each tick mark represents a length of $\goldD{0.1}$, or $\goldD{\text{ one tenth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{2 tenths}}$ after $\purpleE{4}$.    We can write the fraction as $\purpleE{4}\goldD{\dfrac{2}{10}}$ or $\blueD{\dfrac{42}{10}}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: The same number line as above showing that 4 plus 2 tenths equals 4.2

hints.content: We can use a place value chart to help us write $\purpleE{4 \text{ ones}}+\goldD{2 \text{ tenths}} $.   $\purpleE{4}$ and $\goldD{ \text{2 tenths}}$ equals $\blueD{4.2}$.   Ones | $.$ |  Tenths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $\purpleE{4}$ | $.$ | $\goldD{2}$
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Fraction:  $\dfrac{42}{10}$  * Decimal: $4.2$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a fraction and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 8 to 10, with 10 equal sections between each whole number. A point labeled question mark is 7 sections to the right of 8.

hints.content: There are $10$ equal distances between each two whole numbers on the number line.
Each tick mark represents a length of $\goldD{0.1}$, or $\goldD{\text{ one tenth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{7 tenths}}$ after $\purpleD{8}$.    We can write the fraction as $\purpleD{8}\goldD{\dfrac{7}{10}}$ or $\blueD{\dfrac{87}{10}}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: The same number line as above showing that 8 plus 7 tenths equals 8.7

hints.content: We can use a place value chart to help us write $\purpleD{8 \text{ ones}}+\goldD{7 \text{ tenths}} $.   $\purpleD{8}$ and $\goldD{ \text{7 tenths}}$ equals $\blueD{8.7}$.   Ones | $.$ |  Tenths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $\purpleC{8}$ | $.$ | $\goldD{7}$
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Fraction:  $\dfrac{87}{10}$  * Decimal: $8.7$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a fraction and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 9 to 11, with 10 equal sections between each whole number. A point labeled question mark is 4 sections to the right of 9.

hints.content: There are $10$ equal distances between each two whole numbers on the number line.
Each tick mark represents a length of $\goldD{0.1}$, or $\goldD{\text{ one tenth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{4 tenths}}$ after $\purpleD{9}$.    We can write the fraction as $\purpleD{9}\goldD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$ or $\blueD{\dfrac{94}{10}}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: The same number line as above showing that 9 plus 4 tenths equals 9.4

hints.content: We can use a place value chart to help us write $\purpleE{9 \text{ ones}}+\goldD{4 \text{ tenths}} $.   $\purpleE{9}$ and $\goldD{ \text{4 tenths}}$ equals $\blueD{9.4}$.   Ones | $.$ |  Tenths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $\purpleE{9}$ | $.$ | $\goldD{4}$
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Fraction:  $\dfrac{94}{10}$  * Decimal: $9.4$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a mixed number and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 2 to 4, with 10 equal sections between each whole number. A point labeled question mark is 6 sections to the right of 3.

hints.content: There are $10$ equal distances between each two whole numbers on the number line.
Each tick mark represents a length of $\goldD{0.1}$, or $\goldD{\text{ one tenth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{6 tenths}}$ after $\purpleD{3}$.    We can write the fraction as $\purpleD{3}\goldD{\dfrac{6}{10}}$ or $\blueD{\dfrac{36}{10}}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: The same number line as above showing that 3 plus 6 tenths equals 3.6

hints.content: We can use a place value chart to help us write $\purpleD{3 \text{ ones}}+\goldD{6 \text{ tenths}} $.   $\purpleD{3}$ and $\goldD{ \text{6 tenths}}$ equals $\blueD{3.6}$.   Ones | $.$ |  Tenths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $\purpleD{3}$ | $.$ | $\goldD{6}$
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Mixed number:  $3\dfrac{6}{10}$  * Decimal: $3.6$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a mixed number and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 7 to 9, with 10 equal sections between each whole number. A point labeled question mark is 1 section to the right of 7.

hints.content: There are $10$ equal distances between each two whole numbers on the number line.
Each tick mark represents a length of $\goldD{0.1}$, or $\goldD{\text{ one tenth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{1 tenth}}$ after $\purpleD{7}$.    We can write the fraction as $\purpleD{7}\goldD{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ or $\blueD{\dfrac{71}{10}}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: The same number line as above showing that 7 plus 1 tenth equals 7.1

hints.content: We can use a place value chart to help us write $\purpleD{7 \text{ ones}}+\goldD{1 \text{ tenth}} $.   $\purpleD{7}$ and $\goldD{ \text{1 tenth}}$ equals $\blueD{7.1}$.   Ones | $.$ |  Tenths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $\purpleD{7}$ | $.$ | $\goldD{1}$
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Mixed number:  $7\dfrac{1}{10}$  * Decimal: $7.1$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a fraction and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 8.6 to 8.8, with 10 equal sections between each whole tenth. A point labeled question mark is 1 section to the right of 8.6.

hints.content: The length between the labeled tick marks is $\blueD{0.1}$, or $\blueD{1 \text{ tenth}}$.
There are $10$ equal distances between each $\blueD{0.1}$ on the number line. Those distances are each $\goldD{0.01}$, or $\goldD{1 \text{ hundredth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{1 hundredth}}$ after $\purpleD{8.6}$.

images.alt: A portion of the number line above, from 8.6 to 8.7 showing that the point is 1 hundredth to the right of 8.6.

hints.content: $8.6$ and $\goldD{ \text{1 hundredth}}$ equals ${8.6\goldD1}$.   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $8$ | $.$ | $6$  | $\goldD{1}$  We can read the number as $8$ and $61$ hundredths.  We can write the fraction as $8\dfrac{61}{100}$ or $\dfrac{861}{100}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Fraction:  $\dfrac{861}{100}$  * Decimal: $8.61$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a fraction and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 7.4 to 7.6, with 10 equal sections between each whole tenth. A point labeled question mark is 6 sections to the right of 7.4.

hints.content: The length between the labeled tick marks is $\tealD{0.1}$, or $\tealD{1 \text{ tenth}}$.
There are $10$ equal distances between each $\tealD{0.1}$ on the number line. Those distances are each $\goldD{0.01}$, or $\goldD{1 \text{ hundredth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{6 hundredths}}$ after $\purpleD{7.4}$.

images.alt: A portion of the number line above, from 7.4 to 7.5 showing that the point is 6 hundredths to the right of 7.4.

hints.content: $7.4$ and $\goldD{ \text{6 hundredths}}$ equals ${7.4\goldD{6}}$.   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $7$ | $.$ | $4$  | $\goldD{6}$  We can read the number as $7$ and $46$ hundredths.  We can write the fraction as $7\dfrac{46}{100}$ or $\dfrac{746}{100}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Fraction:  $\dfrac{746}{100}$  * Decimal: $7.46$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a fraction and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 3.1 to 3.3, with 10 equal sections between each whole tenth. A point labeled question mark is 2 sections to the right of 3.2.

hints.content: The length between the labeled tick marks is $\tealD{0.1}$, or $\tealD{1 \text{ tenth}}$.
There are $10$ equal distances between each $\tealD{0.1}$ on the number line. Those distances are each $\goldD{0.01}$, or $\goldD{1 \text{ hundredth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{2 hundredths}}$ after $\purpleE{3.2}$.

images.alt: A portion of the number line above, from 3.2 to 3.3 showing that the point is 2 hundredths to the right of 3.2.

hints.content: $\purpleD{3.2}$ and $\goldD{ \text{2 hundredths}}$ equals $\purpleD{3.2}\goldD{2}$.   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $3$ | $.$ | $2$  | $\goldD{2}$  We can read the number as $3$ and $22$ hundredths.  We can write the fraction as $3\dfrac{22}{100}$ or $\dfrac{322}{100}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Fraction:  $\dfrac{322}{100}$  * Decimal: $3.22$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a mixed number and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 4 to 4.2, with 10 equal sections between each whole tenth. A point labeled question mark is 3 sections to the right of 4.

hints.content: The length between the labeled tick marks is $\tealD{0.1}$, or $\tealD{1 \text{ tenth}}$.
There are $10$ equal distances between each $\tealD{0.1}$ on the number line. Those distances are each $\goldD{0.01}$, or $\goldD{1 \text{ hundredth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{3 hundredths}}$ after $\purpleD{4}$.

images.alt: A portion of the number line above, from 4 to 4.1 showing that the point is 3 hundredths to the right of 4.

hints.content: $\purpleD{4}$ and $\goldD{ \text{3 hundredths}}$ equals $\purpleD{4}.0\goldD{3}$.   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $4$ | $.$ | $0$  | $\goldD{3}$  We can read the number as $4$ and $3$ hundredths.  We can write the fraction as $4\dfrac{3}{100}$ or $\dfrac{403}{100}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Mixed number:  $4\dfrac{3}{100}$  * Decimal: $4.03$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Describe the location of the point on the number line with a mixed number and a decimal.**

images.alt: A number line from 1 to 1.2, with 10 equal sections between each whole tenth. A point labeled question mark is 9 sections to the right of 1.1.

hints.content: The length between the labeled tick marks is $\tealD{0.1}$, or $\tealD{1 \text{ tenth}}$.
There are $10$ equal distances between each $\tealD{0.1}$ on the number line. Those distances are each $\goldD{0.01}$, or $\goldD{1 \text{ hundredth}}$.
The point is $\goldD{ \text{9 hundredths}}$ after $\purpleD{1.1}$.

images.alt: A portion of the number line above, from 1.1 to 1.2 showing that the point is 9 hundredths to the right of 1.1.

hints.content: $\purpleD{1.1}$ and $\goldD{ \text{9 hundredths}}$ equals $\purpleD{1.1}\goldD{9}$.   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: |:-: |:-:  $1$ | $.$ | $1$  | $\goldD{9}$  We can read the number as $1$ and $19$ hundredths.  We can write the fraction as $1\dfrac{19}{100}$ or $\dfrac{119}{100}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
We can express the location of the point on the number line in the following ways:  * Mixed number:  $1\dfrac{19}{100}$  * Decimal: $1.19$

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Identify the point on the number line and write it as both a fraction and a decimal.**  **Fraction:**    **Decimal:**

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-tenth unit. Tick marks 0, 1, and 2 are labeled. There is a dot at the fourth tick mark to the right of 1.

hints.content: On the number line, the length between each whole number is split into ten equal pieces.   Each of these pieces has a length of $\tealE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ .  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with a tick mark at every one-tenth unit. The one-tenth mark is labeled. There is a blue dot at the fourth tick mark to the right of 1. Above the number line is a curved bracket from 0 to 1 labeled 10 equal pieces. A second curved bracket above the number line from 1 to 2 is labeled 10 equal pieces.

hints.content: Starting at $0$, we can move $\tealE{14}$ lengths of $\tealE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ to get to the point.   [[☃ image 1]]  The point is located at $\tealE{\dfrac{14}{10}}$.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-tenths to twenty-tenths with a tick mark at every one-tenth unit. There is a green arrow starting at zero-tenths and moving right along the number line to fourteen-tenths. There is a blue dot at fourteen-tenths. Above the green arrow is a curved bracket labeled 14 lengths of one-tenth.

hints.content: Starting at $0$, we can also move $\maroonE{1 \text{ one}}$ and $\tealE{4 \text{ tenths}}$ to get to the point.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with a tick mark at every one-tenth unit. There is a pink arrow moving right along the number line from 0 to 1 and a green arrow moving right along the number line from 1 to fourteen-tenths. There is a blue dot at fourteen-tenths. Above the pink arrow is a curved bracket labeled 1 one. Above the green arrow is a curved bracket labeled 4 tenths.

hints.content: We can use a place value chart to write $\maroonE{1 \text{ one}}$ and $\tealE{4 \text{ tenths}}$ as a decimal.  Tens |Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |$\maroonE{1}$|$.$  | $\tealE4$ |
The point on the number line represents the fraction $\dfrac{14}{10}$ and the decimal $1.4$.

question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Identify the point on the number line and write it as both a fraction and a decimal.**  **Fraction:**    **Decimal:**

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-tenth unit. Tick marks 0, 1, and 2 are labeled. There is a dot at the eighth tick mark to the right of 1.

hints.content: Starting at $0$, we can move $\tealE{18}$ lengths of $\tealE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ to get to the point.   [[☃ image 1]]  The point is located at $\tealE{\dfrac{18}{10}}$.

hints.content: Starting at $0$, we can also move $\maroonE{1 \text{ one}}$ and $\tealE{8 \text{ tenths}}$ to get to the point.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with a tick mark at every one-tenth unit. There is a pink arrow moving right along the number line from 0 to 1 and a green arrow moving right along the number line from 1 to eighteen-tenths. There is a blue dot at eighteen-tenths. question.content: Look at the number line below.    **Identify the point on the number line and write it as both a fraction and a decimal.**  **Fraction:**    **Decimal:**

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 3 with tick marks every one-tenth unit. Tick marks 0, 1, 2, and 3 are labeled. There is a dot at the sixth tick mark to the right of 2.

hints.content: On the number line, the length between each whole number is split into ten equal pieces.   Each of these pieces has a length of $\tealE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ .  [[☃ image 1]]

Above the number line is a curved bracket from 0 to 1 labeled 10 equal pieces. A second curved bracket above the number line from 1 to 2 is labeled 10 equal pieces. A third curved bracket above the number line from 2 to 3 is labeled 10 equal pieces.

hints.content: Starting at $0$, we can move $\tealE{26}$ lengths of $\tealE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ to get to the point.  [[☃ image 1]]  The point is located at $\tealE{\dfrac{26}{10}}$.

There is a blue dot at twenty-six tenths. Above the green arrow is a curved bracket labeled 26 lengths of one-tenth.

There is a pink arrow moving right along the number line from 0 to 2 and a green arrow moving right along the number line from 2 to twenty-six tenths. There is a blue dot at twenty-six tenths. The point on the number line represents the fraction $\dfrac{26}{10}$ and the decimal $2.6$.
